A preliminary solid waste disposal plan
was completed in February, 1972.
Further planning, now underway, should
seriously consider all resource recovery
possibilities.

A preliminary plan for handling storm
drainage problems is now being pre-
pared, but additional funds will be
needed to complete a detailed plan and
program.

The services and utilities described
above all have interjurisdictional impli-
cations. It is recommended that the
local governments in the region formally
cooperate in planning, financing, and
operating water, sewer, storm drainage,
and solid waste disposal services.

Estimated costs for water and sewer
facilities to 1990 is $930 million in
constant dollars. The 1980 annual cost
for debt retirement and operating these
facilities is estimated at $104 million.

Transportation: A high level of service
for the movement of people and goods
and the efficient transmission of

~ energy, consistent with enhancement

of the esthetic, physical, economic
and social environment.

By 1990 travel within the region will
double to more than 4.5 million person
trips per day.

People relying on public transportation
often are very limited as to where they
can go for medical, education, and
recreation services. About 450,000
people in the region live in households
without an automobile.

The ab'ility of the region to maintain
and expand its economic base will
depend to a large degree on the ability
of the transportation system to move
people to employment centers, which
are becoming increasingly decentral-
ized.





The transportation system must also
accommodate significant increases in
the amount of freight to be moved.
Freight movement facilities, including
highway and rail connections between
freight terminals and their markets are
particularly important to the Port of
Baltimore and Friendship, International
Airport.

An adequate supply and distribution of
energy must be provided in order to
sustain and enhance the quality of life.
Two of the most important energy
challenges facing the region are: to meet
the growing needs and to meet them in
a manner that will minimize harmful
effects to the environment.

Recommendations

An integrated public transportation
system costing $1.8 billion centered on
a regional rapid transit system is essen-
tial to meet the needs of people not
having access to an automobile, to
provide mobility in high density areas
which cannot be adequately served by
highways alone, and to encourage in-
vestment and development at key activity
centers. Two types of rapid transit are
proposed—trains operating in excess
of 75 miles an hour and express and
limited service buses.

Expansion and improvement of the
highway system at a cost of $2.4 billion
is recommended. Almost 85 percent of
the cost of the recommended con-
struction would be in the urban areas
of the region.

Actions should be taken to reduce
travel demand by instituting more
restrictive parking policies, modifying
shift patterns, and improving bus
service. ;

In order to keep the Port of Baltimore
competitive with other east coast ports,







improvements to both terminal facilities
and highway and rail connections are
essential,

Major improvements are required at
Friendship International Airport, and
general airports will be needed in Anne
Arundel, Carroll, Harford and Baltimore
Counties.

Taxation policies which penalize the
added cost of placing transmission lines
underground, in order to protect the
environment, should be eliminated.

Transportation facilities and energy
transmission corridors should be so
designed and constructed as to mini-
mize disturbance to the natural environ-
ment and residential communities.





Goal

Shelter and Community Development:
Adequate choice from a sufficient
supply of decent homes in suitable
environments within economic reach
of all citizens of the region.

While housing is generally adequate for

‘most people in the Baltimore Region,

it is not yet a reality for a substantial
number of households. The region’s
primary housing problem is a shortage
of adequate units, particularly for low
and moderate income families. For
minority group citizens, equal housing
opportunity is still more hope than
reality.

Some 90,000 of the region’s housing
units are now inadequate and must be
rehabilitated or replaced. The largest
portion of this deficit exists in Baltimore
City. However, some of the more rural
counties contain a substantial percent-
age of inadequate housing.

The cost of housing, particularly for
home buyers, has skyrocketed in recent
years. This has been a major factor in
the growing trend toward the develop-
ment of multi-family rental housing.



There is an increasing awareness that
not only the house, but also its environ-
ment, with attendant public services,
must be improved before the nationally
adopted goal of a “‘decent home in a
suitable living environment’ can be
achieved for all residents of the Balti-
more area.

Patterns of racial and economic dis-
crimination remain in the Baltimore
Region, despite some progress during
the past decade. :

Recommendations

Adequate and suitably located housing
for all of the region’s residents can be
achieved before 1990 provided the
following conditions are met and main-
tained: high volume production and re-
habilitation; realistic income gains and -
housing cost stability; intensified con-
cern about the environment and the
ability of local governments to cope
with urban development pressures;
realization of equal opportunity in both
housing and employment.

Of major importance is closing still
evident gaps in the supply and location
of low- and moderate-income housing
throughout the region. A plan for the
balanced distribution of such housing
will be prepared soon as a supplement
to this General Development Plan.

Meeting region-wide housing needs by
1990 will require 20,000 new and re-
habilitated dwelling units yearly. Their
timing and location should be guided by
a balanced distribution plan. Such a
plan should be prepared soon by the
Area Housing Council for RPC consid-
eration.

Wider use of rehabilitation, replacement
and maintenance programs will be re-
quired to maintain and improve the



general quality of the housing stock,
particularly in areas with older housing.
New housing construction meets for the
most part, additional needs for housing
in new and undeveloped locations.
Continued used of existing housing in
adequate condition meets the bulk of a
community's overall housing needs.
Rehabilitation of as many as 4,000 units
a year will be required to meet total
housing needs. :

Means should be found to hold down
factors contributing to high housing
costs, which go beyond actual construc-
tion. Such factors as high land prices,
land development charges, building
code compliance costs, and closing out-
lays must be reduced.

The quality of residential neighborhood
environments should be maintained and
improved. Rehabilitation and mainte-
nance efforts are necessary in older
neighborhoods throughout the region.
Strong planning and development con-
trols will be required in new suburban
communities. The expanded use of inno-
vative and efficient planned unit devel-
opment should be encouraged.

Development of adequate housing for
all in suitable environmental surround-
ings must be accompanied by equitable
and broad access to employment and
income opportunities throughout the
region. Stronger efforts than those of the
past will be required to achieve this.





Goal

Health: Provide for the best level of
physical and mental health for every
person at all stages of life, and for an
environment which contributes posi-
tively to healthy individual and family
living.

Issues

While many of the resources necessary
to meet the above goal are currently
available, a system is lacking to link the
resources in order to bridge gaps in
service and avoid duplication.

Health indicators for the region show a
less favorable status of health for its
residents than for the State of Maryland
as a whole.

Although health care is now seen as a
right rather than a privilege, many people
lack the means to purchase it. Many of
those who can purchase it are frustrated
in their attempts to find timely and
appropriate service.

The health care system is essentially
sickness-oriented, with few resources
committed to preventing illness or
maintaining positive health.

From 1960 to 1970 the demand for
emergency services in the region has
resulted in a 133 percent increase in
visits to hospital emergency rooms. A
substantial portion of visits were for
non-emergency purposes, because
health care is not readily available for
many people outside the hospital.

Certain weaknesses have been identified
in emergency service for those who
require immediate medical care because
of life-threatening or disabling condi-
tions. They are due in part to the limited
training given to ambulance technicians
and the current practice of transporting
the patient to the nearest hospital
instead of the hospital best able to
handle his injury or illness.

While there are as many psychiatric
hospital beds within the region as there
are medical/surgical beds, mental health
services are grossly underfunded.

A steadily increasing elderly population
within the region demands attention to
the many implications of long-term care.

Recommendations

Maintain and improve a strong health
planning process, with widespread and
active participation by the community.

Formulate and apply health criteria for
engineering and conserving the natural
and man-made environments.

Link resources into service coalitions,
and eliminate duplication and gaps.

Assure every person in the region ready
access to effective and appropriate
health care resources, including primary
(first contact) care.

Improve the effectiveness of the region’s
hospitals in meeting routine care needs.





Develop an emergency medical system
with the quality and capacity to provide
appropriate medical care.

Provide a full range of mental health
services.

Develop alternatives for institutional long
term care which will enable individuals
(especially the elderly, chronically ill,
and disabled) to maintain themselves
independently and with dignity in a home
or community setting.

Provide adequate and effective institu-
tional services for those persons requir-
ing specialized medical care or rehabili-
tation. :

Find and apply mechanisms to assure
the financial viability of the region’s
health system.





Goal

Safety and Justice: Adequate and
equal justice and protection of life and
property against crime, fire, traffic
hazards, and other threats to personal
and public safety.

Issues

The Criminal Justice Planning Board of
this region identifies as the number one
priority in crime prevention the early
recognition of delinquent tendencies,
which start when behavior problems
appear during the first years of a child’s

school life.

Police agencies are still struggling with
problems related to administration, field
services, communications, and training.

On both the circuit and district court
levels, operational dﬁfficulties, such as
overloaded dockets and insufficient per-
sonnel, are causing congestion, slow
administration of justice, and a narrow
range of rehabilitative expectance.

One of the most serious deterrents to
adult rehabilitation is the inability of
local institutions to properly classify,
screen, and diagnose incoming prison-
ers, many of whom are in need of
special programs.





Another major obstacle to adult rehabili-
tation is the acute overcrowding of jails

and prisons, and their inability to sepa-

rate juvenile from older offenders. }

A key problem in the rehabilitation of the
juvenile delinquent is the limited number }
of available alternatives to confining him
in an institution.

Adult rehabilitation is impeded by a
serious lack of community correctional
alternatives such as halfway houses,
adequate probation services, and work
release or educational furlough
programs.

Local institutions have a need for addi-
tional manpower allocations and contin-
uing training programs if rehabilitation
is to be effective.

k]

Recommendations

A vast increase in funds is needed for
community-based delinquency preven-
tion programs.

Immediate police needs are additional
personnel and specialized equipment,
an improved modern communications
network, expansion of management and
technical training programs, and intensi-
fied community relations programs.

Measures recommended for increasing
the efficiency of the adjudication process
include: management studies of prose-
cutors’ offices; utilization of automatic
data processing; assignment of para-
professionals for staff support work;
easing of staff limitations in the State’s
Attorney's office to improve pre-trial
screening and case preparation; up-
grading and expanding psychiatric
evaluation services; extension of the
State’s Attorney’s services to juvenile
and district courts.

Goal

Economic Well-Being: Adequate and
rewarding employment for everyone
able to work; opportunity for securing
goods and services necessary for
satisfactory life in today’s society; eco-
nomical and effective delivery of public
assistance to those who cannot other-
wise provide; sound governmental
fiscal bases and balanced economic
development in the region.

In planning for job opportunities and the
provision of goods and services, it is
essential to estimate as accurately as
possible the future growth, composition,
and distribution of the region’'s popula-
tion.

Birth rate, death rate, and migration data

~ indicate that the total population of the

region will be 2,800,000 by 1990 com-
pared with 2,070,000 in 1970.

In 1990, one quarter of the region’s pop-
ulation will be black, the same propor-
tion as exists today. Eighty percent of
the region’s 1990 black population will
live in Baltimore City. That will represent
an accelerated movement into suburban
counties during the seventies and

|__eighties, doubling the number of black |

residents there.

Between 1970 and 1990 the elderly
population will grow from a little over 8
percent to almost 10 percent.

Although Baltimore City population will
remain close to its present 900,000, it is
expected that the city’s percentage of
the region’s total population will decline
from 45 to 30 percent. On the other
hand, significant growth is anticipated in
the suburban counties.

By 1990, 50,000 people living in the
region will work in Metropolitan Wash-
ington.



Over the period 1970-1990, employment
will increase by about 300,000 jobs to a
level near 1,200,000, and the economy
will continue its shift from goods-
producing to service-producing activi-
ties. Service-job opportunities will tend
to develop near rapidly expanding su-
burban communities, but MetroCenter,
Baltimore’s central business district, will
continue as the financial-administrative-
business service hub of the region.

During the coming decade, there will be
small employment gains in such indus-
tries as construction, transportation,
communications, and public utilities, but
the greatest gains will be in the areas of
finance, trade, government, and other
types of services. In all industry groups,
there should be a notable increase in the
demand for professionals, and a mod-
erate increase in the managerial cate-
gories.

While median family income in the
_region was over $10,000 in 1970, almost
170,000 residents are dependent on
some form of public assistance. Poverty
is most concentrated in the urban core,

appropriate service.

The health care system is essentially
sickness-oriented, with few resources
committed to preventing illness or
maintaining positive health.

emergency services in the region has
resulted in a 133 percent increase in
visits to hospital emergency rooms. A
substantial portion of visits were for
non-emergency purposes, because
health care is not readily available for
many people outside the hospital.

require immediate medical care because
of life-threatening or disabling condi-
tions. They are due in part to the limited
training given to ambulance technicians
and the current practice of transporting
the patient to the nearest hospital
instead of the hospital best able to
handle his injury or illness.

While there are as many psychiatric
hospital beds within the region as there
are medical/surgical beds, mental health
services are grossly underfunded.

A steadily increasing elderly population
within the region demands attention to
the many implications of long-term care.

active participation by the community.

Formulate and apply health criteria for

Link resources into service coalitions,

Assure every person in the region ready
access to effective and appropriate
health care resources, including primary
(first contact) care.

Improve the effectiveness of the region’s
hospitals in meeting routine care needs.





Develop an emergency medical system
with the quality and capacity to provide
appropriate medical care.

Provide a full range of mental health
services.

Develop alternatives for institutional long
term care which will enable individuals

independently and with dignity in a home
or community setting.

Provide adequate and effective institu-
tional services for those persons requir-
ing specialized medical care or rehabili-
tation. :

Find and apply mechanisms to assure
the financial viability of the region’s
health system.

Goal

Economic Well-Being: Adequate and
rewarding employment for everyone
able to work; opportunity for securing
goods and services necessary for
satisfactory life in today’s society; eco-
nomical and effective delivery of public
assistance to those who cannot other-
wise provide; sound governmental
fiscal bases and balanced economic
development in the region.

In planning for job opportunities and the
provision of goods and services, it is
essential to estimate as accurately as
possible the future growth, composition,
and distribution of the region’'s popula-
tion.

Birth rate, death rate, and migration data

~ indicate that the total population of the

region will be 2,800,000 by 1990 com-
pared with 2,070,000 in 1970.

In 1990, one quarter of the region’s pop-
ulation will be black, the same propor-
tion as exists today. Eighty percent of
the region’s 1990 black population will
live in Baltimore City. That will represent
an accelerated movement into suburban
counties during the seventies and

|__eighties, doubling the number of black |

residents there.

Between 1970 and 1990 the elderly
population will grow from a little over 8
percent to almost 10 percent.

Although Baltimore City population will
remain close to its present 900,000, it is
expected that the city’s percentage of
the region’s total population will decline
from 45 to 30 percent. On the other
hand, significant growth is anticipated in
the suburban counties.

By 1990, 50,000 people living in the
region will work in Metropolitan Wash-
ington.



Over the period 1970-1990, employment
will increase by about 300,000 jobs to a
level near 1,200,000, and the economy
will continue its shift from goods-
producing to service-producing activi-
ties. Service-job opportunities will tend
to develop near rapidly expanding su-
burban communities, but MetroCenter,
Baltimore’s central business district, will
continue as the financial-administrative-
business service hub of the region.

During the coming decade, there will be
small employment gains in such indus-
tries as construction, transportation,
communications, and public utilities, but
the greatest gains will be in the areas of
finance, trade, government, and other
types of services. In all industry groups,
there should be a notable increase in the
demand for professionals, and a mod-
erate increase in the managerial cate-
gories.

While median family income in the
_region was over $10,000 in 1970, almost
170,000 residents are dependent on
some form of public assistance. Poverty
is most concentrated in the urban core,
but is also found in the rural outer
reaches of the region beyond suburban
development. Poverty is not confined to
the jobless. Fully 70 percent of male
heads of households with incomes be- |

low the officially defined poverty level

have some form of employment.

Many citizens are unable to par@icipate
in the economy because of various
forms of discrimination on the basis of
race, age, or sex, as well as geographic
separation from job opportunities in the
suburban counties.

An increasing number of jobs will call for
skills which require specialized educa-
tion and training. Because of the influx
of young persons into the labor force
during-the past few years, a crisis in
matching skills and work experience to
jobs is occurring.



Interdependence of the several jurisdic-
tions within the regional economy is
evident in_a number of ways, most
notably in the patterns of commuting be-
tween work places and residences. The
city and counties share unequally in
fiscal burdens and public benefits.

Recommendations

Jobs should not only offer employment,
but also opportunities for advancement
at wages sufficient to permit a decent
standard of living.

Discriminatory employment practices
should be identified and abolished.

Efforts should be made to improve public
transportation and to increase the availa-
bility of housing in outlying areas in
order to expand suburban job opportuni-
ties for inner-city residents. Major em-
ployers and the jurisdictions in which
they locate have a responsibility for mak-
ing housing available to workers at
appropriate prices and rents.

Local economic development activities
should be linked to manpower training
and development programs in order that
occupational requirements of industry
can be balanced with the skills of the
labor force. ¢
